html:
9.27.17  5:09 pm   9.26.17  1:27 am    I like to take other people's texts and use them as lyrics. what do you think bill?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201709260127

9.26.17  1:27 am   writing the music is the real fun part for me, just laying down the chords and instrumentation. i like it! but 40 instrumental songs later, it feels like i'm in the same place as when i began--my skills are better, but i haven't gotten to say anything, and i need to move forwards. i've made 3 songs with words, and it's important. they were good, except recording vocals drives me crazy so the production value on that is subpar.
you've really gotta have words if you wanna be clear and specific in your meaning. but lyrics only come to me sometimes, one idea at a time, and in between i'm left drifting. again, putting words to music is some of the most fun i've had making anything. but i really don't know how to just get jumpstarted at will. how can i conquer this?

     i'm not sure, but it's important to remember that lyrics and music help each other. in other words, if you are good with music, which i suspect you are because you've been doing it along time, theoretically you could probably get away with making any lyric sound good. so try random starting places, like random word generators or something, as a starting point, and then make it a challenege to see if you can make it work

you've really gotta have words if you wanna be clear and specific in your meaning. but lyrics only come to me sometimes, one idea at a time, and in between i'm left drifting. again, putting words to music is some of the most fun i've had making anything. but i really don't know how to just get jumpstarted at will. how can i conquer this?

     i'm not sure, but it's important to remember that lyrics and music help each other. in other words, if you are good with music, which i suspect you are because you've been doing it along time, theoretically you could probably get away with making any lyric sound good. so try random starting places, like random word generators or something, as a starting point, and then make it a challenege to see if you can make it work

html:
9.27.17  12:20 pm   When I write down music, I always get confused about sharps, flats and natural symbols. Like if you have a note outside of the key signature and you put a flat,sharp or natural symbol on it, by the next measure are you supposed to assume that if that same note has no symbol then it's back to normal? Or if the note is altered in one clef, but not the other, do I put a sharp/flat/natural symbol on just the one clef and leave the other one unaltered?

     What if there's a modulation, do I put the new key signature in the middle of the score, or do I just adjust the sharps and flats accordingly?

     My strategy is just to write everything as if it's in the key of C.

     Notes that are sharp I write the sharp symbol, notes that are flat I write the flat sumbol. I never write the natural symbol, and if a note is played with a sharp or flat multiple times in the same bar, I write the symbol each time (instead of just once). This works fine for me, because usually the only per son who reads my sheet music is me. And this system makes sense to me.... but is this a bad strategy if I were to share my music with other people?Like if I were to write something out for some horn players or a piano player or whatever, would this system throw them off do you think? 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201705232021

5.23.17  8:21 pm   Let's say you were writing something in B-flat major. And at the beginning of one measure, you have a natural on an E-flat in the left hand. Would you also write a natural on an E if there were one in the right hand in the same measure? Or do you assume that the natural applies to every E in that measure, not just the E that is one the same line/space as the first E?

     ah, that is a good question. i'm sure everyone will chime in saying it's one way or the other, but from what i've seen, there is no clear answer. that's why it's good to use 'courtesy accidentals' which is when you put the accidental (that's the sharp/flat/natural symbol) in parentheses
original_html:

Or if the note is altered in one clef, but not the other, do I put a sharp/flat/natural symbol on just the one clef and leave the other one unaltered?

     What if there's a modulation, do I put the new key signature in the middle of the score, or do I just adjust the sharps and flats accordingly?

     My strategy is just to write everything as if it's in the key of C.

     Notes that are sharp I write the sharp symbol, notes that are flat I write the flat sumbol. I never write the natural symbol, and if a note is played with a sharp or flat multiple times in the same bar, I write the symbol each time (instead of just once). This works fine for me, because usually the only per son who reads my sheet music is me. And this system makes sense to me.... but is this a bad strategy if I were to share my music with other people?Like if I were to write something out for some horn players or a piano player or whatever, would this system throw them off do you think?
